keyTakeAways: Work has begun to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) after a four-week blackout, following the establishment of rare 'ceasefire zones' by the UN.
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has emphasized that off-site power restoration is essential for nuclear safety and security.
Both Ukraine and Russia accuse each other of intentionally cutting power lines—Ukraine claims Russia tested reconnection with the Russian grid; Russia blames Ukrainian shelling.
The ZNPP lost connection to its sole remaining power line last month, forcing operation on emergency diesel generators for over 20 days.
The plant has experienced ten grid outages since the war began, with this being the tenth.

Russia continues to conduct strikes on Ukrainian energy infrastructure, including a two weeks prior strike on a substation in Slavutych that caused a three-hour blackout at the former Chernobyl plant.
Ukrainian officials state that the Russian occupation and military aggression are the root cause of radiation threats in Europe.
Russian-controlled plant staff claim that Russian military support is critical for repairs due to active shelling by Ukrainian forces.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Work is underway to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) in Ukraine after a four-week blackout, the longest since the war began. The restoration effort follows the establishment of rare 'ceasefire zones' by the UN, enabling the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to coordinate repairs. The IAEA director Rafael Grossi stressed that off-site power is vital for nuclear safety, and both Ukraine and Russia blame each other for the outage—Ukraine accusing Russia of intentional power cuts to test grid reconnection, while Russia blames Ukrainian shelling. The plant has suffered ten grid outages since the war began, and recent Russian strikes on Ukrainian energy infrastructure, including a strike on a substation in Slavutych, have raised concerns about cascading risks to other nuclear facilities. Ukrainian officials maintain that Russian military aggression and occupation are the root causes of radiation threats in Europe, while Russian-controlled plant staff claim that military protection is essential to carry out repairs amid active shelling.
title: Work underway to restore power at Ukrainian nuclear plant as UN announces rare local ‘ceasefire zones’
